Is this karma definitely to be experienced or not?
Answer: Four sentences should be made.
There is karma that is one's own karma.
This karma is definitely not to be experienced.
Namely, karma that has already attained the present retribution.
And karma whose retribution has already arisen and is being experienced.
This karma's retribution has already reached the final stage.
This word final has many meanings.ğŸ”½There is the final one thousand eons.
There is the final one hundred eons.
There is the final eon.ğŸ”½There is the final one thousand years.
There is the final one hundred years.
There is the final year.ğŸ”½There is the final month.

There is the final instant.
What is the final one thousand eons?
It is like a single karma that can lead to an eighty-thousand-great-eons lifespan in the neither-perception-nor-non-perception realm.
When one resides in the last thousand eons,
this karma is one's own karma.
This karma will definitely not experience retribution.
Because it has already reached the final stage of retribution.
What is the last hundred eons?
It is like a single karma that can lead to a ten-hundred-eons lifespan in the heaven of no anxiety.
When one resides in the last hundred eons,
this karma is one's own karma. This karma will definitely not experience retribution.
Because it has already reached the final stage of retribution.
What is the last eon?
It is like a single karma that can lead to a sixty-four-eon lifespan in the heaven of universal purity.
When one resides in the last eon,
this karma is one's own karma.
This karma will definitely not experience retribution.
Because it has already reached the final stage of retribution.
What is the last one thousand years?
It is said that a single karma can lead to a lifespan of sixteen thousand years in the Heaven of Free Enjoyment of Manifestations by Others.
When they reach the last thousand years of that lifespan,
this karma is their own karma.
This karma will definitely not experience its ripening.
Because it has already reached the stage of the final ripening.
What is the last hundred years?
It is said that a single karma can lead to a lifespan of one hundred years in the Northern Continent of Kuru.

this karma is their own karma.
This karma will definitely not experience its ripening.

This karma will definitely not experience its ripening.

This karma will definitely not receive retribution.

This karma will definitely not receive retribution.

Question: Why did he compose this treatise?
Answer: In order to make the doubtful attain certainty.
As it is said, the two causes that lead one to fall into evil destinies,
namely, karma to be eliminated by the path of seeing and karma to be eliminated by the path of cultivation.
As for the stream-enterers,
although they have already permanently eliminated karma to be eliminated by the path of seeing,
they are still unable to eliminate karma to be eliminated by the path of cultivation.
Some may doubt,
that the stream-enterers should fall into evil destinies.
Or they may further doubt,
that they should have already eliminated karma to be eliminated by the path of cultivation.
In order to make those doubts attain certainty,
It shows that the one who has entered the stream.
It shows that even though the stream-enterer has not yet permanently eliminated the karma to be eliminated through cultivation,
they will definitely not fall into evil destinies.
Therefore, this treatise is composed.
If a stream-enterer
has unwholesome karma that can lead to suffering,
and its ripening has not yet matured, they should fall into evil destinies. By what path are they obstructed and do not fall?
The answer is: The two types of bonds bind sentient beings and cause them to fall into evil destinies.
Namely, the bonds to be eliminated by insight and the bonds to be eliminated by cultivation.
The stream-enterers,
although they have not yet permanently eliminated the bonds to be eliminated by cultivation, have already permanently eliminated the bonds to be eliminated by insight.
Lacking one provision, they do not fall into evil destinies.
Just as a cart with two wheels can carry a load,
a bird with two wings can fly through the sky, but lacking one is not possible.
This is also like that.
Therefore, the stream-enterers do not fall into evil destinies.
The explanation in the original treatise is like this.
However, there are those who say:
The foolish fall into evil destinies, but the wise do not.
Because all stream-enterers are wise ones.
Those who fall into evil destinies are not noble ones, while all stream-enterers are noble ones.
Those with evil intentions and harmful intentions fall into evil destinies.
Those with good intentions and harmless intentions do not, because all stream-enterers have good intentions and are harmless.
Those who violate the precepts fall into evil destinies.
Those who uphold the precepts do not, because all stream-enterers uphold the precepts.
Because they have already attained the firm ship of the precepts loved by the noble ones.
Furthermore, there are those who say:
All stream-enterers attain non-analytical cessation with regard to evil destinies.
If dharmas attain non-analytical cessation,
those dharmas will never appear again.
Therefore, stream-enterers do not fall into evil destinies.
Other masters say:
If there are those who do not see the faults of evil conduct and the merits of good conduct,
they will fall into evil destinies. All stream-enterers truly know and see the gains and losses of good and evil.
Due to forgetfulness,
Although they temporarily give rise to evil karma, they do not fall into evil destinies.
Some say:
The view of the aggregates has not been eliminated and not fully known.
Those who create evil karma may fall into evil destinies.
All stream-enterers have already eliminated and fully known the view of the aggregates.
Although they temporarily give rise to evil karma,
they do not fall into evil destinies.
As the World-Honored One said:
If the view of the existence of a self has been eliminated and fully known,
one is endowed with five merits.
First, it obstructs the three evil destinies.
Second, it prevents the five heinous crimes.
Third, it liberates from various evil views and practices.
Fourth, it makes an end to the endless cycle of birth and death.
Fifth, at the time of death, the mind is clear and bright.
Some say:
Because the wisdom of stream-enterers purifies the belly,
even if they have evil karma, they do not fall into evil destinies.
It is like two people eating what should not be eaten.
One has weak internal fire and what is eaten is not digested, leading to great suffering.
First, the internal fire is strong, and what is eaten is easily digested without increasing great suffering.
Thus, ordinary beings and stream-enterers,
although both experience objects and create unwholesome karma, the belly of wisdom of ordinary beings is impure.
Because there is no fire of the holy path, they fall into evil destinies and experience various severe sufferings.
Because the belly of wisdom of stream-enterers is pure,
they only experience slight suffering in the human and heavenly realms.
Some say:
Stream-enterers are born from the holy lineage of the TathÄgatas, Arhats, and Perfectly Enlightened Ones, who are as numerous as the sands of the Ganges River.
Although they have evil karma, they do not fall into evil destinies.
It is like two people who both violate the king's laws.
One is an ordinary subject and is severely punished,
while the other is a prince and is only reprimanded.
Thus, ordinary beings and stream-enterers both create evil karma, but because ordinary beings are not of the holy lineage, the evil karma they create leads to the suffering of evil destinies.
Because all stream-enterers are of the holy lineage,
evil karma only leads to slight suffering in the human and heavenly realms.
Some say:
Because the stream-enterer sees the faults of objects.
Although they have evil karma, they do not fall into evil destinies.
It is like two fish both greedily swallowing bait.
One lacks skillful means and swallows the hook, losing its life.
One has skillful means and uses its tail to strike the bait, taking the food without losing its life. In this way, ordinary beings and stream-enterers,
although both experience objects and create unwholesome karma,
because ordinary beings lack the wisdom of the sages, they do not see the faults in what they experience and enjoy.
Deeply attached, they invite heavy suffering.
Because stream-enterers have the wisdom of the sages,
they see the faults in what they experience and enjoy.
Not deeply attached, they only experience light suffering.
Some say:
Because stream-enterers are endowed with tranquility and insight, although they have evil karma they do not fall into evil destinies.
It is like a vulture and a crow both eating a dead body on the water.
Someone shoots an arrow at them.
The vulture, lacking wings, sinks into the water.
The crow, having wings, immediately flies away.
Thus, ordinary beings and stream-enterers,
although they both experience objects and create unwholesome karma,ğŸ”½when struck by the arrow of impermanence,
because ordinary beings lack the wings of tranquility and insight,
they then sink into the waters of the evil destinies.
Because stream-enterers have the wings of tranquility and insight,
they then ascend to the heavens, the human realm, and the realm of nirvana.
Some say:
Stream-enterers and once-returners,
because their minds are pliable,
because they accord with nirvana,ğŸ”½because their faith seeds are firm,
and because their faculty of faith is deep,
although they have unwholesome karma, they do not fall into the evil destinies.
It is like the great ocean ordering the myriad streams:
You can now uproot all the trees and gather them to me.
The myriad streams replied:
All can be swept away except the willows.
The ocean asked why.
The myriad streams further said:
The willows have two virtues that cannot be swept away:
First, their roots are deep and solid.
Second, they are soft and follow the current.
Even if the waves are stirred up, they cannot uproot them.
Thus, the meaning of evil destinies is to be deluded and carried away by the current. You can now be swept away.
All those who indulge in desires should gather to me.
The current of delusion replied:
All can be swept away,
except for those of the two fruits.
The evil destinies asked why.
The current of delusion said again:
They possess two virtues and cannot be swept away.
One is the deep and firm root of faith, and the other is the flexible practice of the mind.
The waves of karmic actions cannot sweep them away.
Therefore, those of the stream-enterer stage do not fall into evil destinies.
As the World-Honored One said:
My noble disciples should be able to ascertain for themselves
that they have already exhausted the abyss of the evil destinies of hell, animals, and hungry ghosts,
and so on, in detail.
Question: Why did you compose this treatise?
Answer: In order to make the doubtful attain certainty.
As the World-Honored One said:
If there are bhiká¹£us, bhiká¹£uá¹‡Ä«s, and others
who are able to contemplate and see
the four kinds of purity present in their own bodies,
they should be able to ascertain for themselves:
The pits of the difficult and evil destinies of hell, animals, and hungry ghosts have already been exhausted.
Moreover, the World-Honored One said:
If there are many learned noble disciples,
who are able to contemplate and see
the four kinds of purity present within their own bodies,
those noble disciples should be able to ascertain for themselves that the pits of the difficult and evil destinies of hell, animals, and hungry ghosts have been exhausted.
There are those who doubt this about the stream-enterers.
Do they have the ability to correctly know by means of direct perception the matter of their own exhaustion of hell, animals, hungry ghosts, and so forth?
In order to make them understand that the stream-enterers
only know the previously mentioned matter by means of inference, not by means of direct perception, this treatise is composed.
As for the stream-enterers,
do they have the ability to know by means of direct perception
that the pits of the difficult and evil destinies of hell, animals, and hungry ghosts have been exhausted,
and to ascertain this for themselves?
Answer: They are unable to.
If so, how do they know?
Answer: Because they have faith in the Buddha's words.
That is to say, the World-Honored One said:
If there are bhiká¹£us, bhiká¹£uá¹‡Ä«s, and so forth,
as explained in detail above.
Moreover, the World-Honored One said:
If there are many learned noble disciples,
as explained in detail up to...
They have already exhausted the abyss of the evil destinies of hell, animals, and hungry ghosts.
Question: In this context, hell, animals, and hungry ghosts are already included in the evil destinies.
Why is it said again that they are the abyss of the evil destinies?ğŸ”½Answer: The former is detailed and the latter is concise.ğŸ”½The former is specific and the latter is general.
The former is an exposition and the latter is a summary.
There is no fault of repetition.
There is an explanation:
The word hell refers to hell.
The word animals refers to animals.
The word hungry ghosts refers to hungry ghosts.
The words abyss of the evil destinies
refer to eunuchs, hermaphrodites, and those without genitals or with two genitals.
Because they are the abyss of the evil destinies among humans.
Moreover, there is another explanation:ğŸ”½The words hell and so forth refer to hell and so forth.
The words abyss of the evil destinies refer to those who commit the acts of immediate retribution.
Because they will definitely fall into hell in their next life.
Other masters say:
The words hell, etc. refer to hell, etc.
The words dangerous, evil, and pit refer to those who have severed the roots of goodness.
Because if they do not continue, they will definitely fall into hell.
Other masters say:
The words hell, etc. refer to hell, etc.
The words dangerous, evil, and pit refer to those who are not disciplined.
Because they will fall into evil destinies.
Or some say:
The words hell, etc. refer to the fruits of evil destinies.
The words dangerous, evil, and pit refer to the causes leading to them.
As the World-Honored One said, If you see someone practicing the three kinds of evil deeds,
you should know that you have already seen the evil destinies of hell, animals, and hungry ghosts.
Others also say:
The words hell, etc. refer to the three evil destinies.
The word dangerous specifically refers to hell.
Because in hell there is no ripening of good karma and it is not peaceful.
The words evil destinies refer to hungry ghosts.
Because they are always lacking in resources and go to evil destinies.
The word pit refers to animals.
Because when the eon is formed they are born, and when the eon is destroyed they die, and it is difficult for them to escape.
Other masters say:
The word dangerous generally refers to the three evil destinies.
Because the three evil destinies are extremely dangerous.
The word evil destiny also generally refers to the three evil destinies.
Because the destinies they go to are all defiled and evil.
The word pit also generally refers to the three evil destinies.
Because their bodies and minds are all extremely inferior,
and they dwell in vile and defiled dharmas like a cesspool.
Question: The places of hell, etc., have innumerable kinds of suffering.
How can it be said that the hells, animals, and hungry ghosts have already ended in the present?
Answer: Because all noble ones are not born there,
and because they no longer experience the aggregates, realms, and bases there, it is said that they have already ended.
It is not that they completely eliminate the suffering implements there,
only then are they called ended.
Question: There are also ordinary beings who do not fall into evil destinies.
Why is it said that only the noble ones have exhausted [rebirth in the hells, etc.]?
Answer: Ordinary beings are not definite.
Some do not fall,
and some do fall.
Because they are not definite, it is not said that they have exhausted [rebirth in the hells, etc.].
All noble ones are definitely not reborn in the hells, etc., and therefore it is said of them [that they have exhausted rebirth in the hells, etc.].
Question: As for those who have entered the stream, they have also partially exhausted rebirth in the human and heavenly realms.
Why is it said that they have only exhausted rebirth in the hells, etc.?
Answer: As for those who have entered the stream, there is rebirth and non-rebirth in the human and heavenly realms.
In the hells, etc., there is definitely no rebirth. Therefore, it is said of them [that they have exhausted rebirth in the hells, etc.].
Moreover, those who have entered the stream have attained the four knowledges,
namely, the knowledge of suffering, the knowledge of its origin, the knowledge of its cessation, and the knowledge of the path.
They have not yet attained the knowledge of exhaustion and the knowledge of non-production.
Question: Why is this treatise composed again?
Answer: In order to make the doubtful attain certainty.
That is to say, there are those who doubt,
because those who have entered the stream only inferentially know what has been exhausted.
They should also inferentially know the four noble truths.
Moreover, there are those who doubt,
Because all stream-enterers have already severed the afflictions and fruits eliminated by the path of seeing.
They should also have already attained the knowledge of exhaustion and non-arising.
In order to eliminate their doubts, it is shown that stream-enterers have already attained four knowledges.
They have not yet attained the knowledge of exhaustion and non-arising.
Because they have attained the four knowledges, they have present knowledge and realization of the four truths.
Because they have not yet attained the knowledge of exhaustion and non-arising,
they infer that they have already exhausted [suffering]. This treatise is composed for this reason.
Question: Why have stream-enterers not yet attained the knowledge of exhaustion and non-arising?
Answer: To exhaust all births,
sever all afflictions,
and accomplish all tasks,
one must then give rise to the knowledge of exhaustion and non-arising.
Stream-enterers have not exhausted all births,
severed all afflictions,
or accomplished all tasks.
Therefore they have not yet attained the knowledge of exhaustion and non-arising.
Some other masters say:
Only after permanently exhausting all realms, destinies, births, places of birth, aging, sickness, and death,
can one realize the knowledge of exhaustion and non-arising.
It is not that those who have entered the stream permanently end all realms, destinies, places of birth, birth, old age, sickness, and death.
Therefore, they have not yet attained the knowledge of exhaustion and non-arising.
As the World-Honored One said:
Because of studying to harm the nÄga, observing it, after seven days, the KoÅ›ala family will surely perish.
What is meant by studying to harm?
And so on, it is explained in detail.
Question: Why is this treatise composed?
Answer: In order to distinguish the meaning of the sÅ«tras.
As the sÅ«tras say:
Bhiká¹£us should know,
because of harming the wet vessel, destroying the dignity of the precepts,
because of studying to harm the nÄga, observing it, after seven days, the KoÅ›ala family will surely perish.
What is meant by harming the wet vessel?
It refers to the lord of the KoÅ›alas,
ViÅ›vÄmitra,
who let his madness run wild and harmed the ÅšÄkyas.
These ÅšÄkyas are the mothers of that [ViÅ›vÄmitra].
Since childhood, they have often eaten from the same vessel.
The world calls this a wet vessel.
Killing them while being intimate with them and turning one's back on this intimacy is killing the wet-nurse's child.
Therefore, it is said to be killing the wet-nurse's child.
Some say:
It should be said to be killing the wet face, referring to the ÅšÄkyas who shed tears and begged for mercy.
Not sparing the wet face, one goes to kill them.
Some say:
It should be said to be killing the wet eyes.
Referring to the ÅšÄkyas whose eyes are filled with tears of sorrow, not giving rise to compassion, one instead kills them.
Because of this karma, they will certainly be destroyed.
What is meant by destroying the dignity of morality?
It means destroying both worldly and undefiled precepts.
As for those who plan to harm,
those who plan refer to those who have attained the fruit of stream-entry and once-returning.
They plan to harm, and because of planning to harm, they will cause that royal lineage to soon be destroyed.
What is meant by the NÄga's contemplation?
The word NÄga here refers to an arhat.
The arhats carefully contemplate them.
Or the Blessed One is called the Great NÄga.
It means that the World-Honored Buddha will carefully contemplate.
After seven days, the KoÅ›ala family will surely perish.
Because of learning to harm.
On the seventh day, the family of VirÅ«á¸haka will be completely destroyed.
Western masters say:
Because of learning to harm the KoÅ›ala family, on the seventh day they will surely perish.
Now, in order to analyze the meaning explained in that sutra, this treatise is composed.
What is meant by learning to harm?
Answer: There is a learner.
Not yet free from desire.
When harmed by others, he thinks:
May they suffer the loss of a beloved child.
Why is a learner harmed by others?
Answer: For three reasons.
Namely, because of acting at the wrong time, in the wrong place, and by the wrong means.
Acting at the wrong time means:
Roaming in villages and hamlets during the night.
Being caught by guards on patrol, bound, recorded, interrogated, and harmed in various ways.
Acting in the wrong place means:
It means entering a wine shop, a brothel, a royal palace, a gambling house, and so on.
Being caught by the overseer,
whipped, interrogated, and subjected to various harsh tortures.
Those who engage in improper conduct,
it means those who suddenly enter gardens and fields to trample on others' crops during the farming month.
Being caught by the guards,
and subjected to various forms of harsh punishment. Because of the suffering,
they think like this:
Let them be ruined and let the mother lose her beloved child.
Ruined means dead.
Because the mother and child are separated, it is called the mother losing her beloved child.
Those who are studying have already attained the precepts of non-action.
Why do they then plot to harm like this?
Answer: Because of the suffering, they think like this about themselves:
It is better for me to be ruined and lose my love,
than for me to be tormented by this suffering.
There is no fault in this, as it is not directed at others.
Some say:
They also think like this about others,
but they only want to scold and not to harm.
Why is this?
If they know that this plotting to harm
even down to killing a single ant egg
even to save their own lives, they would not give rise to this thought.
Therefore, this thought is only for reprimand.
Question: Is this learning to plot harm only thinking?
Or does it also involve speaking?
Some say:
Only thinking, not speaking.
Some say:
Speaking is also not a fault.
Because it is for reprimand, not for harming.
Why is this?
If they know that by this verbal action
even down to harming a single ant egg
even to save their own lives, they would not give rise to the thought, let alone give rise to the verbal action.
Question: If a city or town is where parents live,
do learners plot to harm there?
Some say:
They do not.
Some say:ğŸ”½They do plot,
but only for reprimand.
The detailed explanation is the same as before.
Moreover, it is like learners who have already separated from the impurity of desire.
When others harm them, they think, May they fall away from detachment.
May the mother lose her beloved child.
Question: Do they make this statement after falling away?
Or do they plot harm before falling away?
If they make this statement after falling away,
then they have no power to carry out their plot. How can it be quickly accomplished?
If they plot harm before falling away,
since they are free from desire and evil,
how can they give rise to this mind of plotting harm?
Answer: It should be said that
they must have fallen away.
Question: Since they have no power, how can it be quickly accomplished?
Answer: When they are not free from desire, their power is weak.
They give rise to many thoughts of plotting harm before it can be accomplished.
When they fall away from detachment, the power of the superior path assists their mind's vow, and plotting harm is quickly accomplished.
There is another explanation:
When they are not in the state of falling away, gods, dragons, spirits, and ghosts respect their virtue and submit to them.
When they encounter painful conditions and their practice falls away, they plot harm.
The gods and others assist them, causing their affairs to be quickly accomplished.
Question: When non-returners regress, they engage in plotting harm.
Do arhats who regress also plot harm?
Answer: When those beyond training regress, they do not engage in plotting harm.
Because the fruit is superior, even though they temporarily regress, the aspects and actions they perform are not the same as those who regress in training.
Question: If those beyond training who have already regressed still do not plot harm,
how much less so when they have not yet regressed?
If so, how can we understand the sutra's statement? As it says, Buddha Kashyapa scolded the Mara of desire.
At that time, that Mara fell into hell.
Answer: He only scolded and did not wish to harm.
However, when that karma was exhausted, he fell into hell. It is heard that that Buddha, with only one attendant named Far-reaching,
entered the Shalu village to beg for food in order.
At that time, the Mara of desire transformed into a youth,
threw a stone from afar to hit the attendant,
his head broke open and blood flowed all over his face.
He followed the Buddha to the rear.
At that time, the Buddha turned to the right like an elephant king,
and looked back to see such an event.
He scolded the demon, saying:
Why do you create this evil karma that is not your share?
At that time, when the demon's karma was exhausted, he fell into hell.
Therefore, he only scolded him, not wanting to harm him.
Question: When the disciples plot to harm, is it only for themselves or also for others?
Answer: There are also those who do it for others.
In the past, in this country of Kashmira, there was a capital city named Anluo.
Not far from the city, there was a monastery.
Named Shiya.
There was a bhiká¹£u who was an arhat.
Beside the monastery, he was dyeing his kaá¹£Äya robe.
In the city, someone lost a calf.
Searching for it, he came here.
From afar, he asked the bhiká¹£u if he had seen the calf.
The bhiká¹£u replied that he had not seen it.
The man gradually approached.
By the power of the bhiká¹£u's karma, the man sawğŸ”½that the robe resembled an ox hide, the dye was like blood,
the boiled paper resembled meat, and the vessel was like an ox head.
Seeing this, he was startled and angry, scolding him as a great thief.
How could a bhiká¹£u steal my calf and then slaughter it?
He then inflicted severe beatings and bound them to send them to the king.
The king handed them over to the legal authorities to be imprisoned in jail.
By the power of their karma, he caused the disciples
to have no recollection even after many years.
When their evil karma was exhausted, the disciples all regained their memories.
Where is our teacher? They searched and found out that he was imprisoned in jail.
They then jointly petitioned the king, Our teacher is innocent and has been imprisoned for many years.
We request that the king investigate and release our teacher.
The king ordered the legal authorities to quickly release him.
That arhat had been imprisoned for many days.
His robes were torn, his hair long, and he had no appearance of a Å›ramaá¹‡a.
The legal authorities inspected but did not see a bhiká¹£u.
They then returned and reported to the king, There is no such prisoner.
The disciples again petitioned, Our teacher is definitely in there.
Imprisoned for many years, he has lost the appearance of a Å›ramaá¹‡a.
We request that an announcement be made in the prison.
Who is a Å›ramaá¹‡a? The king will release him.
The king did as he was told and ordered it to be proclaimed.
That arhat's evil karma having been exhausted,
as soon as he heard the call, he awoke as if from a dream.
With his spiritual powers, he rose into the sky,
like a goose king soaring in the sky and staying there.
When the king saw this, he fell to the ground in a faint.
Cold water was sprinkled on his face and after a long while he revived.
He lamented his own ignorance for unjustly imprisoning the sage.
He would fall into the evil destinies without any hope of escape.
He then, with his ministers, looked up to the sky and apologized.
We only pray that the sage will forgive our offenses.
At that time, the arhat looked down and said,
I have never given rise to anger towards you.
The king said,
If that is so, please accept us.
The Venerable One, out of compassion, descended to the king's palace.
The king and his ministers rejoiced and praised him.
They shaved his beard and hair and offered him new clothes.
And to his disciples, he made extensive offerings.
With incense and flowers, they escorted him to the monastery.
Among his disciples, there were many sages.
At that time, the arhat exhorted the assembly, saying, Because of my past karma, I have been unjustly imprisoned.
Do not harbor ill will.
Look at the royal capital.
At that time, there was a novice who had attained the fruit of stream-entry.
His body was far away and did not hear these words.
Later, he followed the bhiká¹£us into the royal capital.
Seeing that his teacher was imprisoned, he secretly gave rise to a harmful mind,
thinking, This is an unrighteous city that unjustly imprisons my teacher.
For many years, he has endured hardships.
Alas, the suffering is truly difficult to bear.
At that time, there was a non-human being who respected and had faith in the Three Jewels.
Knowing the novice's thoughts, during that night,
he caused rain and earth to fill the city, completely burying it.
Moreover, in this country, there was a former royal capital.
Not far from the city,
there was a monastery called Zhanzhuoji.
Within it, there was a bhiká¹£u who was an arhat.
He entered deep meditation without closing the door.
There was a man in the city whose wife ran away and took refuge in the temple.
She was seen entering the monks' meditation hall and hiding under a bed.
Her husband later came to the temple and asked the monks.
The monks did not investigate carefully.
They answered, We did not see her.
The husband then searched everywhere and found her under the bed. He caught her and became angry and abusive, saying,
You thief-like bhiká¹£us!
How can you monks hide my wife and indulge with her?
He beat her and tied her up, and took her to the king.
The king handed her over to the legal authorities, as explained in detail above.
The difference from the previous case is that
there was a monk who had gone forth later and attained the fruit of stream-entry.
But he engaged in plotting harm, letting loose a fire,
and burning down the king's capital. Therefore, it is known that there can also be plotting harm for others.
Question: What is the essence of plotting harm for those in training?
Answer: The essence of plotting harm is the volition associated with anger.
The inner dharmas are called plotting harm.
The outer dharmas are called mental rage.
Due to mental rage, the outer sages made a village without a village,ğŸ”½made a city without a city,
made a country without a country.
Because of this, they touched the sin of harming life.
Question: Why do you make both the village and so on completely perish?ğŸ”½Answer: Externally there is no holy path.
Internally there is the holy path. Externally there is no stopping and contemplating.
Internally there is stopping and contemplating.
Externally it is harmful. Internally it is reprimanded.
Externally one also gives rise to added activity.
Internally one merely gives rise to the thought and says it.
Therefore the external sage commits an offense, not the internal one.
Question: Do all those who plan to harm necessarily accomplish their goal?
Answer: This is not definite.
If sentient beings create and increase
greatly powerful karma, the ripening of which is present, then they do not accomplish their goal.
Like in the past there was a Brahmin king named Pushpa who hated and envied the Buddha's teachings.
He burned the scriptures.
He destroyed stupas, destroyed monasteries, and harmed the assembly of monks.
In the border region of the country of Kashmira,
he destroyed five hundred monasteries, let alone other places.
The evil Mara used expedient means to make the Kumbhanda yakshas secretly assist with their power.
Wherever he went, no one could resist him.
He gradually destroyed the Buddha's teachings up to the Bodhi tree.
The tree spirit of the Bodhi tree was called Truth-Speaker.
He thought like this:
This evil king is extremely foolish and violent.
He is about to destroy the Buddhas, World-Honored Ones, as numerous as the sands of the Ganges River.
The place where he defeated the evil demons and attained perfect enlightenment.
He then manifested himself in the form of an outstanding woman.
Standing in front of him.
When the king saw her, he immediately gave rise to lustful thoughts.
The good spirits who protected the Dharma then got their chance.
They killed the king, his army, and the evil spirits, leaving none to escape.
At that time, there were many learners in the Buddha's teachings.
Although they plotted harm, none of them succeeded.
Because the king's power of blessings was great.
Also, like in the past, King Daratada
Entered the country of Kashmira.
Destroyed the Buddha's teachings.ğŸ”½Killed the assembly of bhiká¹£us, destroyed the stÅ«pas,
Ruined the saá¹ƒghÄrÄmas, and burned the scriptures.
At that time, there were many sages in that country.
Although they plotted harm, none of them succeeded.
Because the evil king's power of blessings was great.
For this reason, it is said:
If sentient beings create and increase greatly powerful karma,
the ripening will not be accomplished.ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
